comments.commentBody:
A good friend of mine travels a lot on business. He has figured out (the hard way) how to minimize the stress of air travel. First, he daydreams his way through the TSA security theatre, maintaining a dreamy ovine expression while unquestioningly obeying whatever commands the screeners bellow at him. They never hassle or bother him, since they're always happy to see a cooperative passenger who acts like a sheep. Once he wedges his 6'1 frame into a coach middle seat, he immediately falls asleep and remains that way throughout the flight, except perhaps to visit the loo if the flight is long enough.

How he manages this preternatural feat is completely beyond my ken. Except that he has always excelled at at falling and remaining asleep. (I've once timed him, and found that he could fall asleep on demand in less than a minute.) He also has the ability to begin daydreaming the moment something becomes boring, retaining just enough attention to spring instantly alert when he's asked a question or his name is called. That may well be the indispensable skill set for surviving modern air travel, however rare it is among H. sapiens.

I'll also offer my own approach, essentially the opposite of my friend's. I have no need to travel for business, so for pleasure I take only staycations. Before each day's thoroughly planned adventure, I enjoy a great night's sleep in my own bed. Then I set out by car or bus to discover and explore some fascinating places in my home town. I end the day as it began, blissfully asleep in my own bed dreaming of the next day's discoveries. Low stress on my mind and body, on my wallet, and on our beleaguered feverish planet. What could be better?

Obviously, neither approach is appropriate (or even desirable) for everyone.

Some airline mileage plans are really good about upgrades and it is worth it to work on accumulating points with these airlines just to be able to upgrade to business. Swiss Air has good mileage plans, and an upgrade can usually be purchased with miles (sometimes with cash in New York) on overseas flights. British Airways has a great frequent flier plan, my long-haul experience with them often included an upgrade to first from business every 3 or 4 flights. The worst I have experienced is paying for "extra comfort" seats in economy on an overseas flight with Continental--not worth a dime. Seat guru is very useful.

Boobus Americanus...  What do they care?  If they can feel secure in their miserable lives then bring it on..  In the race between liberty and security; being "safe" trumps any amorphous concept of "freedom"
Kafka would be proud.

I am amazed at how many readers of what is arguably the most progressive national newspaper seem to be OK with the premise that folks can be perpetually black listed.  Never knowing why you were included in such a list and never being able to challenge the suspicions that got you blacklisted seems preposterous. At a time in which racism and Islamophobia run rampant having such a system guarantees that some people will be perpetually harassed by the authorities. The moment we accepted that whatever the government might wish to do to protect us from terror is completely A-OK we accepted the violation of our constitutional protections. Shame on the Bush administration for establishing this Kafkaesque state of affairs and double-shame on the Obama administration for doing nothing to change it. No wonder the right-wing Tea Party loonies are enjoying such popularity. Collectively we have enabled the worst of us, the worst in us, to take the leading voice in shaping who we are and where we should go. Shame, really, on all of us.

This is very typical of the Bush administration's approach to "security" that persists even after its creators are gone. It starts with an arrogant insistence on pretending to be infallible. Somehow it's considered an unacceptable security risk to acknowledge that the Homeland Security apparatus is capable of error. So of course they must never admit to making a mistake, and certainly must never correct a mistake once its existence has escaped the shroud of secrecy.

It continues with a belief that "national security" and the perpetual state of "War" makes individuals and their rights and civil liberties expendable. So if the Warriors make a mistake and put someone on a list who is ultimately cleared of suspicion, it's entirely appropriate to keep them on the list "just to be safe." Whoever put them on the list clearly had a good reason for doing so, and that reason stood up to the vetting process. Even if further investigation fails to turn up specific evidence of terrorism (or any evidence at all), that still doesn't prove the person is not a threat. Everyone would surely agree that it's better that the "suspect" continue to serve their life sentence of the extra-judicial punishment associated with the list than to allow any risk to national security, no matter how small.

And besides, what career bureaucrat would want to risk being blamed for removing a "suspect" from the list if that suspect were later implicated in a crime? Better to affirm the life sentence than to take that risk. And besides, the bureaucrat will never be held accountable to anyone for depriving a citizen of liberty without due process. For that matter, the "suspect" will never even know who decided on that deprivation, and possibly not even why it was "necessary."

Even if we accept this abrogation of due process as "necessary for national security after 9/11," is there any evidence that this high price has bought us any actual security?

The Bill of Rights is not conditional. It was designed by the founders of our nation to protect us against the overweening power of government. It is in times of emergency that that protection is needed the most. Just ask the Japanese Americans who were interned during World War II or the American Muslims who have been harassed and surveilled since 9/11. Right now the score is government 10, people 0.

Right now the vast majority of Americans don't believe their government can solve the problems, political, economic and social, that we face. But people think giving the FBI absolute power can protect them?

The evil of the system is that the FBI is both "prosecutor" and "judge".  Granted, "not guilty" is not the same as "innocent"; and suspicion should not necessarily be "beyond a reasonable doubt" to put or keep a name on a watch list; but at least after an acquittal, there should be "probable cause".  In our criminal justice system, probable cause is determined by a judge or a grand jury in order to put a check on an overzealous (or worse) prosecutor.  The same standard should be used for the watch list.  Preventing someone from using commercial aircraft can even be compared to a form of imprisonment in that it can  severely restrict a person's movement.

"He also defended the idea of the watch list, saying the government would be blamed if, after a terrorist attack, it turned out the perpetrator had attracted the suspicions of one agency but it had not warned other agencies to scrutinize the person."

That about covers it.

Nobody wants to be holding the hot potato when the next bomb goes off, so all of us "free" citizens of the US pay the price, to keep various bureaucrats' jobs safe in case the worst happens. USA = CYA.

Considering that the justice system is not perfect (an acquittal, as the OJ Simpson case demonstrated to many, is not the same as innocence), the watch list seems to be an equally imperfect but appropriate way to monitor people that pose a potential risk. Being on a watch list is not the same as being declared guilty; extra questioning is not the same as being unfairly locked up. I am usually quite the civil libertarian, but in this case I am willing to give the government the benefit of the doubt. Certainly people whose lives have been disrupted by the list could disagree, but I find it reassuring that a "reasonable suspicion" must still be established to keep someone on the list. Critics will inevitably make comparisons to Stalin's Russia or East Germany, but those sorts of claims are overblown and unhelpful. We live in a healthy democracy, and the fact that the government released these papers in the first place is an indication of just how off-base the dramatic accusations of totalitarianism really are.

It's the 1950s all over again. The U.S. Passport office had a list of Americans who weren't allowed to travel because the Passport office decided, in their own dictatorial authority, that they weren't patriotic.

One of them was Linus Pauling, who wasn't allowed to travel because he opposed nuclear weapons and supported nuclear disarmament. For a scientist like Pauling, that did substantial damage, because he couldn't travel to scientific conferences where his work and the work of others were discussed.

Some people think that if Pauling had been allowed to travel to England, where some of the major work on DNA had been done, Pauling and not Watson and Crick would have discovered that the DNA molecule was in the shape of a double helix.

I hope Pauling's Nobel Prize in peace (in addition to his Nobel Prize in chemistry) made up for that.

Don't worry folks, it's just the government being paranoid and protecting itself. That, and they need a paycheck, right? I'm sure most on the list are probably no threat at all, but it looks good when comming up with the budget to submit. Besides, who's raelly the terrorist? Are you scared?

dear on line editor, The FBI decision is a sensible one ,A person may be acquitted in the basis ofevidence or argument advanced but the alleged accused will nurture theill l feeling with in him and plan to carry on the terrirst acts more boldly hence keeping  watch listis the right decisions dated wednesday Sept 28th 2011 time 0915 Hrs Ist
If you think this is bad, try to unsubscribe from OnStar!
Round up the usual suspects.

Not sure who is the bigger problem?  The rats, informants, spies, spooks, creeps, mercs, and hit men that our government now employs with routine against it's citizenry or the sorry stupid cowards among us who accept their absurd lies for all this Soviet like police state indecency.
And yet the NY Time's would throw the constitution out the window and STRONGLY advocates for the removal of 2nd Amendment Civil Rights based upon this joke of a list.  Disgusting.

And the problem is.....? Trust is so depleted, but most of the time most of the people do the right thing, and don't abuse power. Some do,of course, but not nearly enough to offset the benefits of protecting the public. Dismissal or "not guilty" often doesn't mean anything. Let law enforcement do its job, and, please, stop the histrionic Kafka rants.

To our childrens generation that will be nothing. They are giving their privacy away for free to Facebook to exploit for perpetuity.
Now for our grandchildrens generation - they will look at their parents with pity. The following generations will treasure privacy above all else and there will be ways to ensure it.

I didn't like the title very much either. We Veterans don't like thinking of ourselves as victims or damaged.  We aren't victims of anybody (except maybe bureaucracy on bad days) and damaged sounds like damaged goods, which no Veteran is. But the headline does catch your attention, which is what headlines are for. But let's not just sit around and wring our hands. Those of us of sound mind and body should reach out to Wounded Warriors programs near us and offer to lend a helping hand. Any little thing you can do to give a caregiver a break or some support would be deeply appreciated, I am sure.
Take these kids home.
Assurant Health just sent their renewal notice for my spouse's individual policy.  The rate is going up 27%.  Because they can do it.
I have never been able to comprehend why business didn't push hard for single-payer when the health-care debate was raging.

Every time health insurance premiums increase is an example of financial selection. We are allowing this to happen because we are misinformed about what a public option means. A public option will regulate the health industry in such a way that premiums will have limits, so that financial selection does not happen. It is not right the wealthy survive and live longer, healthier lives than those with limited means. It is time to do the right thing. Please call or write your representatives and explain this is wrong and that you want it changed. We need a public option to level the playing field. Remember, all humans are created equal, and as such, we should be allowed to live equally, healthy lives.

where's my public option?

oh yeah, Obama didn't fight for that, either!

but, he wants US to fight for his re-election?
